awd_titl_txt: Constructing Endohedral Fullerenes Using Open-Cage Fullerenes and Heterofullerenes
awd_abstract_narration:
Professors Alan L. Balch and Marilyn M. Olmstead of the University of California-Davis are supported by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Division of Chemistry to develop new methods for the preparation of endohedral fullerenes (nano-sized soccer ball-like carbon cages encapsulating metal ions).  The synthetic methods are designed to carefully, and selectively, control the insertion of metal atoms into fullerenes, where the atom will be stabilized.  Endohedral fullerenes have only been prepared in minute quantities in a gas phase process.  They have already shown promise in medical imaging technology as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) contrast agents (using paramagnetic gadolinium) and X-ray contrast agents (using the strong X-ray absorber lutetium).  The project is focused on the development of new methods for the preparation of endohedral fullerenes in large quantities to facilitate their practical use for such diagnostic medical imaging and other possible technological applications.  Students at college and high school levels are involved in the project and trained in state of the art synthetic and structure characterization techniques.  Several outreach activities, including a chemistry peer mentoring program, and seminar courses, such as " Symmetry in Art and Science" and "Chemicals and their Effect on California History" are being developed.         
  
In this project, known chemical procedures are used to fashion holes in the fabric of the fullerene cages of C60 and C70 to form open-cage fullerenes.  These open cage structures frequently have Lewis base sites suitable for metal ion bonding near the orifice. Subsequently, metal ions are attached to these open cage fullerenes and eventually inserted into their interior. Reduction of the cage is used to attract the metal ion through the opening and into the interior. These reactions are monitored by spectroscopic means and the products, including metal ion complexes of the open cage fullerenes with metal ions on the outside and on the inside, are isolated and structurally characterized, particularly by single crystal X-ray diffraction.  Once the metal center enters the cage, chemical reactions are used to begin to close the hole in the fullerene network.  Physical properties, such as ability to function as MRI contrast agents and X-ray contrast agents, of the new endohedral species will be examined. The project is also designed to examine two new synthetic routes to make macroscopic amounts of metallo-heterofullerenes, carbon cages with some of the carbon atoms replaced with metal atoms. Such metallo-heterofullerenes have never previously been obtained as solids that can be characterized through spectroscopic and X-ray crystallographic means.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Fullerenes (Buckyballs) such as C60 are molecular forms of carbon that involve sixty or more carbon atoms arranged to form a closed cage with an exterior available for chemical manipulation and a protected interior void. Metalloheterofullerenes, such as C59Pt or C58Ir, are fullerenes in which one or two carbon atoms are replaced by a metal atom and have only been detected in the gas phase, whereas fullerenes can be prepared in macroscopic amounts. Endohedral fullerenes are carbon cages containing atoms such as nitrogen or uranium, molecules such as H2 or CO, or clusters of atoms such as Sc3N or Sc4O2 inside the cage.  Endohedral fullerenes have been shown to have interesting and potentially useful properties that could be used as relaxation agents for magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or a single molecule magnets.  Unfortunately, endohedral fullerenes have only been prepared in milligram quantities and a scale up of the present methods of synthesis has been elusive.  Nevertheless, this project has been able to provide valuable structural information on several endohedral fullerenes including Tb2O@C2(13333)-C74 and Ho3N@C2(22010)-C78 that involve exceptions to the isolated pentagon rule, which allows the prediction of structures for pristine fullerenes.  We also continued to develop cocrystallization with metalloporphyrins as a means to obtain well-ordered crystals of fullerenes and endohedral fullerenes for structural studies by single crystal X-ray diffraction.

The present project was designed to develop a new avenue for the formation of endohedral fullerenes and metalloheterofullerenes.  Synthetic methods had already been developed to cut holes into the surface of C60 and C70.  These holes had been shown to allow access of small molecules like H2 and H2O into the interior of the cage utilizing pressure to force the molecule inside.  Our project was designed to explore the possibility of introducing metal ions or atoms into the interior through the openings in the cage.  In order to get the metal ion inside the cage, we planned to reduce the cage chemically or electrochemically to form an anion that would host the metal cation.  Thus, we undertook structural studies of certain open cage fullerenes to access the size of the opening in them and possibility of placing a metal center inside the hole.  We also examined the reactivity of metal complexes with open cage fullerenes.   We have found that the carbon atoms on the rim of the opening are unusually reactive toward the additions of metal complexes.  Our studies have shown that the reactivity of these open cage fullerenes differs significantly from that of closed cages.  The area around the opening is particularly susceptible to chemical reactions, frequently in ways that are unexpected.  For example, the reaction of Pt(PPh3)3 with C60 forms the simple adduct (Ph3P)2Pt(C60) with the platinum atom bonded to two carbon atoms of the cage.  However, Pt(PPh3)3 reacts with the open cage fullerene known as MMK-9 to form an adduct, (Ph3P)2PtMMK-9), in which a carbon-carbon bond on the rim of the cage is broken and a platinum atom inserted into the fabric of the cage.  This carbon-carbon bond cleavage occurs at room temperature to form an adduct that was produced in good yield, is stable to air, and is capable of electrochemical reduction.  In contrast, (Ph3P)2Pt(C60) is sensitive to air and readily dissociates in solution.  The formation of the adduct, (Ph3P)2PtMMK-9), offers an opportunity to close the opening to form a metalloheterofullerene. In other related chemistry, we have shown that the (Ph3P)2Pt unit can replace a heteroatom in an open cage fullerene in another unprecedented reaction.  Additionally, we explored the preparation as well as the chemical and spectroscopic behavior of several new metal complexes that we expected to react with open-cage fullerenes, but sadly such reactions did not occur.

Research on this project was negatively impacted by COVID-19.  Our supply chain for making open cage fullerenes by undergraduate students supervised by graduate students initially was effective but was completely disrupted once the labs were shut down.  We never fully restored that supply chain.

 


Last Modified: 10/06/2024
Modified by: Alan L Balch
